briefTitle: Effects of Docosahexaenoic Acid (DHA) on Fetal Cardiac Outcomes
officialTitle: The Effects of Docosahexaenoic Acid (DHA) on Fetal Cardiac Outcomes
summary: DHA, a type of fatty acid, is important in early development, both in terms of reproductive physiology of gestation and in postnatal behavioral and cognitive function. In adults, DHA has been shown to lower triglycerides and is important to cardiovascular health and autonomic control, lowering heart rate and blood pressure and increasing heart variability. Little is known about how fatty acids impact cardiac control in infants, children or the fetus. Our hypothesis is that maternal DHA supplementation (600 mg/day) will lower fetal HR and increase fetal HRV.
